TopicTitle: How to take care of betta fish?

Articles.Content:
Well, my sister was stupid and needed a hobby, she decided to get a beta fish.

She bought a starter kit, fish bowl and the fish. How do we care for it?

Also how many times a week do we need to clean the bowl? We have little tablets to drop in to clean.
Well, update it once in a while, keep the users posted, and hopefully you\'ll release on time. ;D

Heheh. Heheheh...

As far as I know, betta fish really only need feeding; there\'s not much else involved. Google can find more info for you, though.
And bowls alre not good for fish, you need an aquarium for keeping fish.
Last time we kept a fish in a bowl, they were both unconscious after 2 weeks. So yeah, bowls suck.
Betta fish don\'t care; they are often kept, while at the store, in cups not much larger in diameter than the fish are in length.

The stores don\'t keep animals good at all. The only thing they want is to sell them fast.

Anyone, please keep animals in appropriate conditions! If you don\'t want to build a large enough cage for your hamster instead of some cheap plastic crap, keeping animals is not for you.

Google knows how to care for a betta fish. Came back with these two as first results.

Got an ehow artical. I need to clean once a week, all the water needs to be dumped.

I also need to stop tapping the glass when I think it\'s dead. I also need to keep my cat away from it. Any ideas on that?

> 
> all the water needs to be dumped.

Actually, the links I\'ve posted says that changing all the water at once is bad for the fish. You\'re supposed to swap a quarter of the tank water out per week, using a siphon to clean up poo and dirt as you drain it. 

They also talk about the right temperature and PH you need for the water. 

It doesn\'t seem like betta\'s need a filter or aeration system.

You need to do your homework completely.

A few years ago, I had one of these fish. I did ABSOLUTLY EVERYTHING WRONG: I used a fish bowl, I changed the water all at once, I kept the water absolutely stagnat (no O2 in the water for the fish) and I even forgot to feed it at times. It drowned, suffocating from a lack of oxygen in the water.

TL;DR: I drowned a fish.

> 
> You need to do your homework completely.

I have a better idea. Find someone who wants a betta fish and knows how to take care of it, give it to them, then tell your sister that the fish died because she wasn\'t taking proper care of it and you disposed of it by flushing it down the toilet. Problem solved.

We need to get more fish food, though.

'Beta fish are good with confined spaces..'

But they\'re not good with slowly rotting away in an unfiltered/unheated bowl filled with ammonia from their own waste. 

In the wild bettas can be found in tiny ponds that some might even describe as puddles. But you know what those puddles have? Plants, algae, and bacteria that act as a filtration system to process all the waste products of the animals that live in them.

1. Bettas are tropical fish and they wont last long in an unheated bowel.

2. A bowl without any kind of filtration will slowly fill up with ammonia until you do a water change. The constant build up and reduction of ammonia will stress and eventually kill the fish. Ask your sister how she\'d like to spend her life locked in a closet filled with her own waste and only having it cleaned out once a week. 

Properly cared for bettas can live for upwards of 6 years. Your sisters probably wont last more than a few months.

If she\'s actually interested in keeping it alive she needs to read this and take it to heart. [http://www.aquariumforum.com/f52/anyone-who-has-never-had-betta-2989.html](http://www.aquariumforum.com/f52/anyone-who-has-never-had-betta-2989.html)
